Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Strengthening Resilience of Arid Region Riparian Corridors: Ecohydrology and Decision Making in the Sonora and San Pedro Watersheds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Riparian corridors in arid regions are the narrow ribbons of trees along streams that shelter some of the most important biodiversity in the landscape. The combination of climate change, human withdrawals of water, and land use decisions threaten stream flow and shallow groundwater that is crucial to the maintenance of riparian corridors. Linked biophysical and societal stresses can push riparian systems across critical thresholds, tipping points beyond which restoration to earlier conditions is unlikely. This can cause loss of broader social-ecological resilience; that is, the capacity of systems to retain essential functions, including provision of water and other ecosystem services. This project will improve understanding of how changes in social and natural processes affect the resilience of riparian systems and, by extension, the ecosystem services these systems provide. Research will focus on two adjacent river systems: the Upper San Pedro River, flowing northward from Sonora, Mexico into Arizona in the United States, and the Upper Sonora River, flowing south within Sonora. An agent-based model will be created to translate interactions among environmental conditions, societal rules, and human practices into likely changes to the riparian corridors under study. This project will answer critical questions about coupled human and ecological processes in riparian systems; responses of riparian systems to stresses; and how crossing thresholds can be assessed.

This research will develop new techniques for modeling social-ecological interactions in riparian corridors that will have direct application in the management of stream ecosystems. The project will provide opportunities for stakeholders at all levels, from officials managing natural resources, to individuals visiting riparian corridors, to use science-based tools for informed decision-making. This work engages stakeholders across national boundaries in participatory science and management of ecosystem services. This project will also contribute to education at K-12 grade levels and provide research training for undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Arid-region watersheds are complex social-ecological systems comprised of rivers and linked aquifers, vegetation and habitat within and outside the riparian corridor, and human settlement and related economic activities.

The San Pedro and Sonora River systems present similar ecohydrological change dynamics (shift of winter to summer rains, flood-and-drought cycles, and encroachment of woody plants on grasslands and, in riparian corridors, deep-rooted drought-tolerant species partially replacing native water-loving phreatophytic tree species).  At the same time, these and other transboundary river systems are experiencing a range of contrasting human and economic drivers (smallholder agriculture and ranching alongside intensive mining in Mexico with an increasingly laissez faire environmental regulatory structure, and ex-urban development and recreational activities alongside extensive ranching in the United States with contested institutions for riparian conservation).

The University of Arizona – led project, “Strengthening Resilience of Arid Region Riparian Corridors: Ecohydrology and Decision Making in the Sonora and San Pedro Watersheds,” (NSF-CNH DEB-1010495) conducted integrated field-based research, monitoring, and modeling to enhance understanding of these coupled arid-region watershed systems.  Partners included the Colegio de Sonora and Universidad de Sonora in Mexico and the University of Copenhagen in Denmark.  Stakeholders and collaborative research partners in both the United States and Mexico contributed significantly to the policy relevance and broader impacts of the research.  Additionally, through leveraged support with additional supplemental funding from NSF, a component of the comparative analysis was added in Peru, allowing the research team to extend results and provide more robust assessment of the broader relevance of coupled social-ecological systems research.

The project has proved to be pivotal and innovative in numerous respects.  The project trained over a dozen graduate students and post-docs in the U.S. and Mexico, many of whom are now carrying on their own interdisciplinary coupled-systems research.  The research outputs have comprised peer-reviewed publications, presentations at scientific and practitioner-related conferences, websites, etc.  Additionally, research and policymaker collaborators on the project have greatly extended their interdisciplinary partnerships, contributing to the Americas-wide AQUASEC network (U.S., Mexico, Peru, Argentina, Chile, and Brazil - http://aquasec.org) and global International Water Security Network (Europe, Americas, South Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa - http://watersecuritynetwork.org) for research and policy engagement on water security in arid regions.
